instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that had liquid contact, and the client had already made an ultra-sound.
It has green light, consumes  25mA in PSU, has no USB activity and doesn't power on.
I get this measurements:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.58
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> - 12.58
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER5V</SIGNAL> - 12.58
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL> - 12.58
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> - 19.7
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> - 1.0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> -3.3
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 0
Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
You should reball SMC, as basic step for liquid damaged boards.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If yes, check for pulse at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals at same time.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I get 140V on L7130/1. Is it normal? I also had 94V on L7630/1, but as it seams a little broken i replaced, and after replacement i now have 14.5V. Is it normal?
I don't think that this values are ok, but don't know what to do...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Change the multimeter, or its battery at least.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
I already changed the battery with the same result. It's strange, because all the other measures seams to be right (even on the same coill  on pad2 i get 12.5V). On <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>/23 i also get a strange value of 185V.
Checked with a new multimeter (same model UT61E), with same high values.
Do you think that it are the multimeters?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Possibly wrong settings on the multimeter; get a cheap one.
On the coils, check DC voltage on output pin.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: with a different multimeter model  i have 12.5V on both pins

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Do you get any pulse at <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> coil?
Check diode mode to ground.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
HI, it was the <RESISTOR>R1963</RESISTOR>. I notice the it was a little dark and replaced, and after replacement it started to work.
Does it make sense to you, or could it be the heat applied to the <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Broken <RESISTOR>R1963</RESISTOR> will stop the power on sequence; it must be 0 ohm.
Problem should be fixed now...
